page.title: 07BURNT OAK
page.content: Burnt Oak was once four fields bounded by the Roman road Watling Street on the west,and the Silkstream on the east.The name comes from the Roman practice of burning one side of an oak tree to mark a boundary. Burnt Oak is part of the Manor of Hendon recorded in the Domesday Book, and was once John the Goldbeater's farmland. The London County Council bought this land in 1924 and built the Watling Estate to rehouse people from Inner London. Watling residents, when interviewed about changes in the area over the last five decades, regularly cited streets being dirty and full of rubbish in 1985. Also many thought the streets too narrow to cope with modern traffic and parking. The loss of two cinemas and lack of sports/youth facilities were felt to deprive the area's young people.
